tit.e: The Satchodohi (Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen Domains)
The Satchodohi (Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen Domains)
The Satchodohi (Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen Domains)

sen.j: 薩長土肥（さっちょうどひ）は、幕末期、「雄藩」と呼ばれ、かつ、明治維新を推進して明治政府の主要官職に人材を供給した薩摩藩、長州藩、土佐藩、肥前藩4藩の総称。
sen.e: The Satchodohi was called 'Yuhan (powerful domain)' in the late Edo Period, also a generic name of 4 Domains, which were Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen, implemented the Meiji Restoration and supplied people for major government service in the Meiji Government.

The Satchodohi was a generic name of 4 Domains, Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen, which were called 'Yuhan (powerful domain)' in the late Edo Period, implemented the Meiji Restoration and supplied people for major government service in the Meiji Government.
sen.cmt: 原文の文意から「雄藩と呼ばれた薩摩、長州、土佐、肥前」と考えて、変えました。
sen.e: The Satchodohi was a generic name of 4 Domains, Satsuma, Choshu, Tosa and Hizen, which were called 'Yuhan (powerful domain)' in the late Edo Period, implemented the Meiji Restoration and supplied people for major government service in the Meiji Government.

sen.j: その主要人物たちは「元勲」「明治の元勲」「維新の元勲」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: The key people are called 'Genkun (oligarch with merit)', 'Genkun of Meiji', or 'Genkun of the Restoration'.
The key people are called 'Genkun (oligarch with merit)', 'Genkun of Meiji', or 'Genkun of the Restoration'.

sen.j: 薩長土は、幕末、志士たちの交流や薩長同盟・薩土同盟で連携関係を結んでいた。
sen.e: The Satchodo (Satsuma, Choshu and Tosa Domains) formed a coalition from the Satsuma-Choshu Alliance and the Satsuma-Tosa Alliance and relationships from exchanges between patriots of each of these three domains in the late Edo period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The Satchodo (Satsuma, Choshu and Tosa Domains) formed a partnership through exchanges among nationalist patriots from these three domains in the late Edo period and through the Satsuma-Choshu Alliance and the Satsuma-Tosa Alliance.
sen.cmt: 「～で」をthrough(～を通じて、～を通して）の意味と考えました。
sen.e: The Satchodo (Satsuma, Choshu and Tosa Domains) formed a partnership through exchanges held among nationalist patriots from these three domains in the late Edo period, as well as through the Satsuma-Choshu Alliance and the Satsuma-Tosa Alliance.

sen.j: 特に薩長は全国の他の諸藩よりも圧倒的に藩政改革が早く、不平等条約による開国という状況や幕末という時代変化にいち早く対応していたため、殉国者含め、倒幕の立役者となる人材を多く輩出していた。
sen.e: Satcho in particular reformed domain duties overwhelmingly and quickly compared with the other domains and dealt with the uncertainties of the changing times promtly, such as the situation of the opening of the country to the world with the Unequal Treaty and the end of Edo era, so they produced many people, who were the major figures in the overthrow of the Shogunate, including some who became martyrs.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Especially Satcho, having started domain duty reform far earlier than the other domains, were quick to deal with the uncertainties of the changing times such as the chaotic situation caused by the opening Japan to the world by the Unequal Treaty and the ending of the Edo period, so they threw up many major figures in the overthrow of the Shogunate including martyrs.
sen.cmt: 「藩政改革が早く」のくだりは前後関係がわかりやすいように完了形の分詞構文にしました。「倒幕の立役者となる人材」を短くまとめました。
sen.e: Especially Satcho, having started domain duty reform far earlier than the other domains, were quick to deal with the uncertainties of the changing times such as the chaotic situation caused by the opening Japan to the world by the Unequal Treaty and the ending of the Edo period, so they threw up many major figures in the overthrow of the Shogunate including martyrs.

sen.j: 薩長土は、戊辰戦争の頃から、倒幕運動には不熱心だったが藩政改革が進んでおり開明的だった「雄藩」の肥前を仲間とみなし、肥前藩にも明治維新政府に人材を供給させた。
sen.e: The Satchodo had been indifferent to the movement of the overthrow of the shogunate since the Boshin War but considered the Hizen Domain, a 'Yuhan', which had reformed Domain duties and had been in the forefront of the cultural development that was taking place, as their collaborators, and they also let the Hizen Domain supply people for the Meiji Restoration.

The Hizen Domain, which had been indifferent to the movement of overthrowing the Tokugawa shogunate since the Boshin War but had made progress in Domain duty reforms, was one of 'Yuhan,' so the Satchodo considered the Hizen Domain as their collaborator and let it supply its people for the Meiji Restoration government.
sen.cmt: 「倒幕運動には不熱心」だったのは肥前であり、一部を変えました。
sen.e: The Hizen Domain, which had been indifferent to the movement of overthrowing the Tokugawa shogunate since the Boshin War but had made progress in Domain duty reforms, was one of 'Yuhan,' so the Satchodo considered the Hizen Domain as their collaborator and let it supply its people for the Meiji Restoration government.

sen.j: このため、明治政府の上位官職を薩長土肥で一時期ほぼ独占する状態となり、藩閥政治と揶揄された。
sen.e: Because of this, the Satchodohi briefly monopolized almost all the higher ranks of government services in the Meiji Government and were referred to as the domain clique government.
Because of this, the Satchodohi briefly monopolized almost all the higher ranks of government services in the Meiji Government and were referred to as the domain clique government.

sen.j: しかし実際には、新政府発足以来、この4藩出身者の中で熾烈な権力闘争・路線闘争が展開されることによって明治政府が運営されていた。
sen.e: However, virtually since the inauguration of the new government, the Meiji Government was administered in an environment of severe conflict over authority and policy among the former members of the Four Domains.

However, virtually since the inauguration of the new government, the Meiji Government was administered in an environment of severe conflict over authority and policy among the former members of the Four Domains.

However, virtually since the inauguration of the new government, the Meiji Government was administered in an environment of severe conflict over authority and policy among the former members of the Four Domains.

sen.j: 薩長出身者は政府・軍部の中核を占めたが、土肥出身者は一部は明治政府に残りつつも一部は薩長政府を攻撃するという展開となった。
sen.e: The people who came from Satcho were in middle ranks of the government and the military, however one group of people who came from Hizen remained in the Meiji Government but another group made an attack against the Satcho Government.

The people coming from Satcho were in the middle ranks of the government and the military, however, while some people from Hizen remained in the Meiji Government, others made an attack against the Satcho Government.
sen.cmt: 「一部は」をsomeと othersという対の形にしました。
sen.e: The people coming from Satcho were in the middle ranks of the government and the military, however, while some people from Hizen remained in the Meiji Government, others made an attack against the Satcho Government.

sen.j: 明治の国政は、良くも悪くも、この薩長土肥主導による政治であったと言える。
sen.e: For better or worse, it can be said that the affairs of state in the Meiji period were under the leadership of Satchodohi.
For better or worse, it can be said that the affairs of state in the Meiji period were under the leadership of Satchodohi.

sen.j: 1869年（明治2年）、4藩同時に率先して版籍奉還を上奏し、全国諸藩の版籍奉還を導いた。
sen.e: In 1869, the Four Domains simultaneously took the role of national leadership, reported to the emperor, and led the returning of lands and people of the various domains of the entire nation to the emperor.

In 1869, these Four Domains simultaneously took the role of national leadership in submitting a plan of Hanseki-hokan (return of lands and people to the emperor), and led the returning of lands and people of the various domains of the entire nation to the emperor.
sen.cmt: took the role of national leadership「率先して～する」の「～する」の部分をin ～ing形にしました。
sen.e: In 1869, these Four Domains simultaneously took the role of national leadership in submitting a plan of Hanseki-hokan (return of lands and people to the emperor), and led the returning of lands and people of the various domains of the entire nation to the emperor.

sen.j: 1871年（明治4年）、再び4藩同時に率先して廃藩置県を上奏し、全国諸藩の廃藩置県を導いた。
sen.e: In 1871, again, the Four Domains simultaneously took the role of national leadership, reported on the Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) to the emperor, led the Haihan-chiken of the various domains of the entire nation.

In 1871, again, the Four Domains simultaneously took the role of national leadership in reporting a plan of the Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) to the emperor, and led the abolition of the various domains of the entire nation.
sen.cmt: took the role of national leadership｢率先して～する」の「～する」の部分をin ～ing形にしました。
sen.e: In 1871, again, the Four Domains simultaneously took the role of national leadership in reporting a plan of the Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) to the emperor, and led the abolition of the various domains of the entire nation.

sen.j: 1871年（明治4年）7月14日、実質的な最終決済をする参議内閣に薩長土肥一人ずつの参議を供給することとなったため（参議に推された順番で、長州：木戸孝允、薩摩：西郷隆盛、肥前：大隈重信、土佐：板垣退助）、これ以降、薩長土肥出身者が参議の大部分を占めることになった。
sen.e: On July 14, 1871, it was decided to supply one Sangi (councillor) from each of the four domains which made up the Satchodohi to the Sangi cabinet, which made the final actual settlement of constitutional matters (the order of people recommended to become Sangi were: from Choshu, Kogoro KATSURA; from Satsuma, Takamori SAIGO; from Hizen, Shigenobu OKUMA; from Tosa, Taisuke ITAGAKI) and after that a majority of Sangi were people who came from the Satchodohi.

Because on July 14, 1871 it was decided that each domain of Satchodohi should supply one Sangi (councilor) respectively to Sangi cabinet, which virtually made the final settlement of constitutional matters (the members of Sangi were, Kogoro KATSURA from Choshu, Takamori SAIGO from Satsuma, Shigenobu OKUMA from Hizen, and Taisuke ITAGAKI from Tosa, in the order of being recommended), a majority of Sangi were the people from the Satchodohi after that.
sen.cmt: 形式主語itの真主語をthat節にしまし、接続詞Becauseでまとめ、（ ）内を整理しました。
sen.e: Because on July 14, 1871 it was decided that each domain in the Satchodohi should supply one Sangi (councilor) to the Sangi cabinet, which effectively had the final say of constitutional matters (according to the order in which they were recommended, the members of the Sangi cabinet were Kogoro KATSURA from Choshu, Takamori SAIGO from Satsuma, Shigenobu OKUMA from Hizen, and Taisuke ITAGAKI from Tosa); thereafter, a majority of the Sangi cabinet was made up of people from the Satchodohi.

sen.j: 1875年（明治8年）10月、土佐の板垣退助が明治6年の政変に続いて明治政府を再び離脱し、国民を教化しつつ明治政府の外から自由主義的な議会制度を準備する運動を起こす道を歩み始めた。
sen.e: In October, 1875, Taisuke ITAGAKI from Tosa resigned from the Meiji Government for the second time following the political change which happened in 1873 and educated the nation's people as well as initiating a course of action to prepare for the liberalization of parliamentary procedure from outside of the Meiji Government.

In October, 1875, Taisuke ITAGAKI from Tosa resigned from the Meiji Government for the second time following the political change which had happened in 1873, and while educating the nation's people, he initiated a course of action to prepare for the liberalization of parliamentary procedure from outside of the Meiji Government.
sen.cmt: 前後関係をわかりやすくするため「政変」に続く動詞の時制を過去完了にしました。後半の部分をandという接続詞とwhile educatingという接続詞の残った分詞構文にしてまとめました。
sen.e: In October, 1875, Taisuke ITAGAKI from Tosa resigned from the Meiji Government for the second time following the political change which had happened in 1873, and while educating the nation's people, he initiated a course of action to prepare for the liberalization of parliamentary procedure from outside of the Meiji Government.

sen.j: 1881年（明治14年）10月、急進的な議会制度の早急な 実施を求めていた肥前の大隈重信が、明治14年の政変によって明治政府を離脱せざるを得ない事態となり、板垣同様、明治政府の外から明治政府にイギリス的な憲法と議会政治を求める運動を起こす道を歩み始めた。
sen.e: In October, 1881, Shigenobu OKUMA from Hizen, who requested the enactment of a radical parliamentary system, seems to have had to resign from the Meiji Government because of the political change which happened in the same year, and from outside of the Meiji Government he initiated a campaign to seek a constitution like that of Great Britain and a parliamentary government, as ITAGAKI had done.

In October, 1881, Shigenobu OKUMA from Hizen, who requested the enactment of a radical parliamentary system, had to resign from the Meiji Government because of the political change which happened in the same year, and like Itagaki, he initiated a campaign to seek a constitution and a parliamentary government like those of Great Britain from outside of the Meiji Government.
sen.cmt: 「板垣同様」をlike Itagakiと簡単にしました。
sen.e: In October, 1881, Shigenobu OKUMA from Hizen, who requested the enactment of a radical parliamentary system, had to resign from the Meiji Government because of the political change which happened in the same year, and like Itagaki, he initiated a campaign to seek a constitution and a parliamentary government like those of Great Britain from outside of the Meiji Government.

sen.j: 1898年（明治31年）6月、明治政府は、日本最初の政党内閣として憲政党による隈板内閣（首相：大隈重信、内務大臣 (日本)：板垣退助、ともに首班）を成立させた。
sen.e: In June, 1898, the Meiji Government established the Waihan Cabinet (Prime Minister: Shigenobu OKUMA, the Minister of Dometic Affairs (Japan): Taisuke ITAGAKI, both were shuhan [chairman of their respective parties]) organized by Kenseito (a political party in the Meiji period in Japan) as the first party cabinet in Japan.

In June, 1898, the Meiji Government established the Waihan Cabinet (Prime Minister: Shigenobu OKUMA, the Minister of Dometic Affairs (Japan): Taisuke ITAGAKI, both were shuhan [chairman of their respective parties]) organized by Kenseito (a political party in the Meiji period in Japan) as the first party cabinet in Japan.

sen.j: 1914年（大正3年）4月、第1次山本内閣総辞職、清浦奎吾流産を受け、窮した元老は再び大隈重信を首班指名して大命を降下させ、特に昭和戦後に非常に悪名高くなった第2次大隈内閣を成立させた。
sen.e: In April, 1914, due to the mass resignation of the cabinet of the first Prime Minister, Yamamoto, and the abortive attempt to form the Keigo KIYOURA government, the Genro (elder statesmen) had no alternative but to nominate Shigenobu OKUMA as the shuhan again and order him to be imperial commander and allow the second OKUMA Government, which had a terrible reputation, especially after the Showa War, to be established.
